title: Germany’s GroKo on the brink once more
text:
BERLIN — By all rights, Germany’s “grand coalition” should have died ages ago.

From its beginning in early 2018, the tie-up between the country’s two largest political groups — Angela Merkel’s center-right bloc and the Social Democrats (SPD) — faced one plague after another, from disastrous election results to backstabbing to leadership turmoil.

As the warring pair nears the coalition’s halfway mark, the GroKo (the German nickname for the coalition) faces its biggest challenge yet — an SPD leadership contest that is expected to serve as a referendum on the fate of the government.

After seeing the party drop from about 25 percent support to just 20 percent during the previous grand coalition, the SPD base was reluctant to link arms with Merkel again, following the 2017 election. Even though SPD members ultimately voted in favor of renewing the coalition, the split in the party remains, with many rank-and-file members pushing for an early exit.

The party has been led by a triumvirate of senior officials ever since a string of ballot box letdowns earlier this year forced the resignation of Andrea Nahles as SPD leader in June. Responding to the party’s steep slide, SPD mandarins promised more transparency and bottom-up decision-making, beginning with the selection of new leadership.

Murky deals

SPD leaders have been chosen in murky backroom negotiations between party power brokers ever since the workers’ movement was founded more than 150 years ago. In a stark departure with that tradition, the party decided to open the process to all 425,000 party members. And instead of sticking to just one leader, the party’s board encouraged male-female duos to apply.

After several weeks of campaigning and nearly two dozen public debates across the country, six male-female pairs remain in the race. Voting got underway on October 14 and closes Friday. The party plans to announce first round results Saturday, followed by a run-off in late November.

As of early this week, about one-third of party members had voted. Polling has been sparse and a survey this month among SPD members put four of the six pairs within a few points of one another. Michael Roth, Germany’s state secretary for Europe, placed first with 23 percent together with his running mate, Christina Kampmann, a regional politician from North Rhine-Westphalia.

Though neither candidate has a national profile, the pair, by far the youngest on the ballot, has won over crowds with its freshness and unabashed enthusiasm for all things EU (“Our answer to Trump is United States of Europe,” Roth told crowds during the campaign).

Even so, in the same poll, published early this month by Die Welt, 35 percent of respondents said they believed a duo led by Finance Minister Olaf Scholz, the most high-profile figure in the race, would ultimately prevail.

Though Scholz has strong approval ratings in Germany overall, he's controversial among his own party faithful. To them, he represents the SPD establishment that steered the party into the mess it's in to begin with.

It’s an accusation Scholz has difficulty countering. The former mayor of prosperous Hamburg, Scholz, 61, has spent most of his working life in the service of the party, including a stint as general secretary under Gerhard Schröder and as interim party leader. He has been a member of the party’s executive committee since 2001.

What particularly upsets Scholz’s critics, however, is his strict adherence to Germany’s balanced budget. Indeed, in terms of the government’s spending policies, there is little difference between Scholz and his austere conservative predecessor, Wolfgang Schäuble, known and feared across the Continent for his bookkeeping mantra schwarze Null (black zero).

Scholz, who paired with little-known east German politician Klara Geywitz in the leadership race, is also seen as a guarantor that the GroKo will continue.

During the nearly two-dozen regional debates, Scholz often found himself on the defensive.

“In truth, no one really has a clue how this will end” — SPD official from Hamburg

“Olaf, you admit to being a GroKo fan, so why should opponents of the GroKo support you,” an audience member in Hanover asked him.

Scholz answered by trying to steer the conversation toward his many political accomplishments.

Even his close associates acknowledge that his GroKo affiliation is his Achilles' heel.

“In truth, no one really has a clue how this will end,” an SPD official from Hamburg said.

Even as many Social Democrats are convinced the GroKo is to blame for the party’s historic slide, Germans overall continue to support it. More than 60 percent of respondents in a poll last month said they wanted the coalition to finish its term, which ends in the fall of 2021.

A worse outcome

The danger for the SPD is that pulling out early, which would likely trigger a snap election, would do even more damage to the party than sticking it out.

Germany’s recent political history would seem to support that argument. Support for Germany’s liberals, the Free Democrats, soured after the party leader’s sudden decision in 2017 not to enter a three-way coalition with the Christian Democrats and Greens.

The liberals finished well ahead of the Greens in the last election but have since fallen below 10 percent. Meanwhile, the Greens have surged to more than 20 percent.

After the liberals got cold feet, Merkel had no choice but to pursue another GroKo, which most of the players regarded as the least-bad option.

That same reasoning (“the alternative is worse”) has frustrated GroKo death-watchers ever since.

Yet the leadership race gives the SPD’s grand coalition-haters one last chance.

The final decision on the new leadership rests with delegates at a party convention on December 6.

Two of the six pairs on the ballot are avowed GroKo opponents. That means that even if Scholz manages to win the first round, there’s a good chance the runoff will pit the pro- and contra-GroKo camps against one another.

In the most recent poll of SPD members, GroKo opponents Norbert Walter-Borjans, the former finance minister of North Rhine-Westphalia, and Saskia Esken, an MP, placed second, just 2 points behind the leaders.

There’s also the possibility of a last-minute surprise.

The final decision on the new leadership rests with delegates at a party convention on December 6.

Normally, that vote would be little more than a formality after the membership poll. But earlier this week, activist-comedian Jan Böhmermann, best known outside of Germany for taking on Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, threw his hat in the ring.

In his first speech as a candidate, Böhmermann apologized both for the SPD’s backing of social welfare in recent years and for the “bloodless” slate of candidates the party has put forward for its leadership.

Though Böhmermann isn’t on the membership ballot that closes Friday, he has a good chance of putting his name forward at the December convention. It’s unlikely he’ll win, but the avowed GroKo opponent could shift the momentum.

The reason the leadership race represents the last chance for the SPD to pull out of the government is that Germany is slated to take over the rotating Council of the EU presidency in July. A collapse of the government in the midst of the presidency is something even the GroKo’s detractors want to avoid.

By the end of the presidency, Germany’s next general election will be less than a year away.

Even if they don’t get their way in the coming weeks, the SPD rebels can take solace in the knowledge that this is almost certainly the last grand coalition for the SPD in the foreseeable future.

Now that the Social Democrats have been supplanted by the Greens and are tied for third place in the polls with the far-right Alternative for Germany, they’re no longer GroKo material.

description: Social Democrats pick new leadership, which could spell the end of the grand coalition.
